150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et hodieque reliquiae durant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:176" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 45, 70, § 176</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt clari hodieque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:94" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 94</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n40071.12" n="F" level="1"> Connecting final member of a clause: <cit><quote lang="la">fauste, feliciter, prospereque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 1, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab honore, famā fortunisque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pacem, tranquillitatem, otium concordiamque afferat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1</bibl></cit>. — </sense><sense id="n40071.13" n="G" level="1"> In transition to a new subject or thought: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniamque ea natura esset hominis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:20:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 20, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">discriptioque sacerdotum nullum justae religionis genus praetermittit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:12:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 12, 30</bibl></cit>; v. Madv. ad. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:22:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 22, 73</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n40071.14" n="II" level="1"> Repeated, que . . . que. </sense><sense id="n40071.15" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Both ... and</hi> (not in Cæs., once in Cic.; v. Zumpt, Gram. § 338), co-ordinating, </sense><sense id="n40071.16" n="1" level="3"> Similar notions: <cit><quote lang="la">quasque incepistis res, quasque inceptabitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">risusque jocosque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 98</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.17" n="2" level="3"> Contrasted notions: <cit><quote lang="la">meque teque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0981,001:3:2:31" default="NO"><author>Asin.</author> 3, 2, 31</bibl></cit>: mores veteresque novosque tenentem, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:4:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 4, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mittuntque feruntque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:495" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 495</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">noctesque diesque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:16:51" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 16, 51</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.18" n="3" level="3"> Esp. when one or both of the words are pronouns: <cit><quote lang="la">seque remque publicam curabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 9, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quique in urbe erant, quosque acciverant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quique exissent, quique ibi mansissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 22</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.19" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... que</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and ... and</hi>, the first que referring to a previous clause: singulasque res definimus, circumscripteque <pb n="1509" /> <cb n="QUE" /> complectimur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:59:147" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 59, 147</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.20" n="III" level="1"> More than twice. </sense><sense id="n40071.21" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... que ... que</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod mihique eraeque filiaeque erili est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regnaque tristia, Divosque mortalesque turbas regit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:4:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 4, 46</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.22" n="2" level="3"> Four times, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:444" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 444</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">five times,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:344" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 344</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">seven times,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:691" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 691</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.23" n="IV" level="1"> Followed by other conjunctions. </sense><sense id="n40071.24" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... et</hi> (not in Cic., Cæs., Suet., or Nep.): <cit><quote lang="la">peregrique et domi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deus, qui quae nos gerimus auditque et videt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seque et oppidum tradat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 26:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 26, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illosque et Sullam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 104:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 104, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">signaque et ordines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:43:2" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 43, 2</bibl> Weissenb. ad loc.: <cit><quote lang="la">legatique et tribuni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in formulam jurisque et dicionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes gentesque et terrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:30:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 30, 2</bibl></cit> (v. Fabri ad loc.): <cit><quote lang="la">Arpinique et Romani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seque et arma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:4:15" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 4, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seque et delatores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 42</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.25" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... et ... et</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romanique et Macedones et socii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seque et arma et equos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seque et domum et pacem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 37</bibl>. — </sense><sense id="n40071.26" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... ac</hi> (rare, not earlier than Verg.): <cit><quote lang="la">satisque ac super,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:429" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 429</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minusque ac minus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculisque ac mente turbatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">posuitque domos atque horrea fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 182</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seque ac liberos suos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opibusque atque honoribus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 34</bibl></cit>. — </sense><sense id="n40071.27" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... ac ... et</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quos seque ac conjuges et liberos condunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:6:17" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 6, 17</bibl></cit>. — </sense><sense id="n40071.28" n="5" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Que ... et ... ac</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 41</bibl>. — </sense><sense id="n40071.29" n="V" level="1"> Following a conjunction, <hi rend="ital">et ... que</hi>: paratissimi et ab exercitu reliquisque rebus, Brut. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 13</bibl>, a, 5: <cit><quote lang="la">id et singulis universisque honori fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit> (Weissenb. et id); <cit><quote lang="la">occasionally in Cic. (through negligence, acc. to Madvig): igitur et Epaminondas ... Themistoclesque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">officia et servata praetermissaque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 10, 37</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.30" n="VI" level="1"> Que nearly equivalent to autem, sed ..., <hi rend="ital">but</hi> (not in Cæs.): <cit><quote lang="la">studio ad rempublicam latus sum ibique multa mihi advorsa fuere,</quote> <trans><tr>but there</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 3, 3</bibl></cit>.—Mostly after a negative: <cit><quote lang="la">Socrates nec patronum quaesivit nec judicibus supplex fuit, adhibuitque liberam contumaciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:29:71" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 29, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 13, 28 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui non temere movendam rem tantam expectandosque ex Hispaniā legatos censerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 6, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae neque dant flammas lenique vapore cremantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:811" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 811</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n40071.31" n="VII" level="1"> Que is usually appended to the first word of the phrase, but to a noun rather than to a monosyllabic preposition governing it, unless the preposition is repeated: <cit><quote lang="la">de provinciāque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:20:section=48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 20, § 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per vimque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 5, 4, 10</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ab iisque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:33:94" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 33, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sub occasumque solis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 11</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Exceptions are to be found, especially in Liv.: proque ignoto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exque eo tempore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:23:80" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 23, 80</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 34, 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">inque eam rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:39:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 39, 114</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inque eo exercitu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:18:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 18, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inque eam rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:37:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 37, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:57:5" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 57, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cumque eis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:26:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 26, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:26:5" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 26, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:18:2" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 18, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">deque praedā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:11:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 11, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:49:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 49, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 6, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:36:7" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 36, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">transque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:41:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 41, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:14:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 14, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:5:3" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 5, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exque eo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perque somnum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 5</bibl></cit>.—And where the same preposition is repeated que is regularly joined to it: <cit><quote lang="la">haec de se, deque provinciā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:28:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 28, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:59:16" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 59, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:23:10" default="NO" valid="yes">29, 23, 10</bibl>; 31, 5, 4; <cit><quote lang="la">38, 35, 7: de matrimonio Agrippinae, deque Neronis adoptione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:43" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 43 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per senectutem tuam, perque eam, quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>. — <cit><quote lang="la">Where the preposition is dissyllabic it regularly takes the que: interque eos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 20, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:49:7" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 49, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sine scutis sineque ferro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:23:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 23, 64</bibl></cit>. — <cit><quote lang="la">It is rarely annexed to the second word of the clause, when the first word is an adverb: tantos tam praecipitisque casus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tanto tam immensoque campo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 31, 124</bibl></cit> al.—In class. Latin que is not appended to hic, sic, nunc, huc, etc. (v. Madv. ad. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:14:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 14, 40</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">hucque et illuc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">15, 38</bibl>: tuncque <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 7</bibl> (1); <cit><quote lang="la">14, 15.—Que is often misplaced by the poets, especially by Tibullus and Propertius in the latter part of the pentameter: Messallam terrā dum sequiturque mari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:3:56" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 3, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferratam Danaes transiliamque domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:16:11" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 16, 11</bibl></cit>. <cb n="QUER" /></sense></entryFree>
